instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> had pad 8 missing after liquid in the area. I ran a jumper and replaced the chip. It was working for 2 days but now the fan spins for 10 seconds than stops and restarts and keeps spinning.

Some voltages.

[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> 0
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0
[*]<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0
[*]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4
[*]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> When I try and check this voltage the machine shuts down.
[/LIST]
 I have replaced bios and checked SPI traces. Not sure about USB activity but the mouse light comes on.

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltages

1- 3.3

2- 3.3 if connected when powering on, if take probe off and put back on the machine shuts down.

3- 3.4

4- 0

5- 3.4

6- 3.4

7- 3.4

8- 3.4

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
Post <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is there it probably always was but I probably checked it after checking <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> which shuts down the machine. If I had the fan connected I would have realized.

Diode <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.36

Diode <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.64

Voltage = 3.3

CPU stuffed?

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Do you get voltage at L7310/20?

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message:
VCCST power good is required, before enabling VCORE.
Post <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: 820 00165 No VCORE
threads.message: Thanks for sorting that out. It was <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>
